title: Alyssa Milano shares snap of herself nursing daughter after public breastfeeding legalized in the US
text:
She's been a public advocate for feminist causes throughout her career, and now Alyssa Milano is celebrating a new victory.

The 46–year–old actress posted a throwback photo of herself nursing her daughter to Instagram on Monday.

She used the intimate photo to celebrate the legalization of breastfeeding in all 50 US states.

Accomplished: Alyssa Milano, 46, shared a throwback photo of herself breastfeeding from 2014 to celebrate the legalization this summer of public breastfeeding in all 50 US states

Alyssa's photo pictured the Charmed star with her white T-shirt raised as her daughter suckled.

The Insatiable star's shot originates from 2014, when she gave birth to her daughter Elizabella.

She previously posted a series of breastfeeding selfies from the same period in 2016 to celebrate World Breastfeeding Week.

'World Breastfeeding Week 2016 is August 1-7, celebrating links between breastfeeding and the Sustainable Development Goals,' she captioned the first of her previous posts, adding the hashtag '#normalizebreastfeeding.'

Doing her part: Alyssa annually celebrates World Breastfeeding Week in August to help normalized the practice

Last year, Alyssa recorded a short YouTube video advocating for normalized breastfeeding.

'Breastfeeding my children has been one of the greatest joys of my life, and I'm so proud that my body was able to provide them with the sustenance and comfort they needed during their first months of life,' she said while holding her other child, son Milo, now eight.

Lest anyone think she was only interested in promoting breast feeding, she clarified that 'Formula should always be easily available for women who cannot breastfeed or choose not to.'

Finally: Idaho and Utah became the last states to legalized public breastfeeding after a bipartisan group of lawmakers overcame Republican opposition

Alyssa again shared a breastfeeding selfie this past August, though her attention was quickly diverted by the mass shooting on August 3 in El Paso, Texas, in which a gunman shot and killed 22 people and injured 24 more.

Despite the activism of women working to normalize breastfeeding, the practice wasn't legal in public in all 50 US states until July of this year, shortly after the holdout states Idaho and Utah legalized it.

Even then, legalization faced pushback from some lawmakers.

'This seems to say you don’t have to cover up at all. I’m not comfortable with that, I’m just not. It’s really in your face,' Republican State Representative Curt Webb of Utah told the Salt Lake Tribune.

The legislation in Idaho only exempted breastfeeding women from indecent exposure and obscenity laws, rather than establishing a right, a compromise that had to be reached in order to placate Republicans in the statehouse.l

Speaking her mind: The Charmed star has long been an advocate for feminist social causes. In October 2017 she helped re-launch the #MeToo movement, created in 2006 by Tarana Burke, with a tweet; pictured October 16

In addition to her advocacy to normalize breastfeeding, Alyssa has been a vocal advocate in defense of legal abortion and the US Supreme Court's Roe v. Wade decision.

Earlier this year she revealed that she had two abortions within months of each other in 1993 after her birth control methods failed.

She's also noted for re-launching the #MeToo movement, which was originally created in 2006 by Tarana Burke.

'If you’ve been sexually harassed or assaulted write "me too" as a reply to this tweet,' she tweeted in October 2017.

She also shared a screenshot of text reading, 'If all the women who have been sexually harassed or assaulted wrote "Me too." as a status, we might give people a sense of the magnitude of the problem.'
description: Alyssa Milano shared a throwback photo of her nursing to celebrate the legalization of public breastfeeding in all 50 states. Idaho and Utah finally legalized the act over the summer.
